Security

Subscribers want to know that their dependencies handle security responsibly. We want to tell them about any vulnerabilities that affect their dependencies, take some proactive steps to avoid future vulnerabilities, and handle any new vulnerabilities responsibly.

Tell us about historical vulnerabilities

We keep a database of vulnerabilities along with affected package versions. If you've had any security vulnerabilities in the past, when you start lifting your package, we'd like you to tell us about them—there's a place to do this on the lifter dashboard.

We use this information to notify subscribers if they're using any affected versions of your package.

Agree to use responsible disclosure

There are two elements of this:

  • By agreeing to lift your package, we'd like you to agree in principle that you'll follow responsible disclosure practices.
  • If someone reports a vulnerability to you, actually use a responsible disclosure process.

We ask that you add a vulnerability-reporting link and policy to your README or project website. You can create your own process OR you can use the Tidelift reporting page and process. When you start lifting a package, we'll walk you through this in the lifter dashboard.

If you're creating your own process, these projects with mature, detailed security policies might be interesting to see how other projects handle security bugs:

  • Django
  • npm

If you don't want to figure out your own process, all you have to do is link to our reporting page. When we get a report, we'll reach out to you and we'll ask you to work with us on it.

Agree to be responsive to security issues

We'd like you to be responsive around security issues and work to resolve them. Not all reported issues are severe (or even real), but it's important to assess each one and respond.

We aren't imposing a firm time limit or deadline, because we feel it wouldn't be viable for smaller projects, at least not without more support from Tidelift. However, please put security issues at the front of your priority queue.

Tell us about new vulnerabilities

If you're handling a responsible disclosure yourself, please enter the new vulnerability into the lifter dashboard when it becomes public. We'll then notify any affected subscribers.

Use two-factor authentication (or at least unique passwords)

When you agree to become a lifter, we'll ask that you enable two-factor authentication on all sites that are involved in the pipeline from code to package. This will protect your own accounts, while also lowering trojan horse risks for subscribers. This eslint trojan was an example of the kind of problem we're trying to avoid.

In particular, if applicable:

  • Enable 2-factor auth on GitHub
  • Enable 2-factor auth for package publishing
    • npm

For services which do not have 2-factor authentication, please us a strong password unique to each service (most people do this via a password manager).

If you haven't, we know you've been meaning to set up 2-factor authentication and strong passwords. As part of agreeing to lift your package, we're asking you to actually do it.

If your project isn't security-sensitive…

Not all projects parse untrusted input. If a given security task doesn't apply to your project, then you wouldn't be on the hook for that task.

Some security risks can affect any project, though, such as trojan package uploads containing malware.

Future directions

We may ask for a few more security-related tasks in the future, subject to figuring out the details—we want to be sure the details of these tasks are manageable for maintainers and valuable for subscribers. These ideas may or may not happen soon, and may or may not be part of the base lifter agreement.

We'd love to talk about these or your other ideas, get in touch!

Future: Security scanning or linting

There are a number of security analysis tools which proactively look for potential problems. We could run those regularly on lifted projects and ask lifters to read over the report, tagging reported issues as real or false-positives. The value to subscribers would be to quickly detect SQL injection problems, obvious buffer overflows, or other common mistakes.

Future: Signed packages

A simple version of this would be to require signatures, for package managers that support it.
